an4.245:1.1.pli: “Sikkhānisaṃsamidaṃ, bhikkhave, brahmacariyaṃ vussati paññuttaraṃ vimuttisāraṃ satādhipateyyaṃ.
an4.245:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, this spiritual life is lived with training as its benefit, with wisdom as its overseer, with freedom as its core, and with mindfulness as its ruler.

an4.245:1.2.eng: And how is training its benefit?

an4.245:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, mayā sāvakānaṃ ābhisamācārikā sikkhā paññattā appasannānaṃ pasādāya pasannānaṃ bhiyyobhāvāya.
an4.245:1.3.eng: Firstly, I laid down for my disciples the training that deals with supplementary regulations in order to inspire confidence in those without it and to increase confidence in those who have it.

an4.245:1.4.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, mayā sāvakānaṃ ābhisamācārikā sikkhā paññattā appasannānaṃ pasādāya pasannānaṃ bhiyyobhāvāya tathā tathā so tassā sikkhāya akhaṇḍakārī hoti acchiddakārī asabalakārī akammāsakārī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an4.245:1.4.eng: They undertake whatever supplementary regulations I have laid down, keeping them intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred.

an4.245:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, mayā sāvakānaṃ ādibrahmacariyikā sikkhā paññattā sabbaso sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
an4.245:2.1.eng: Furthermore, I laid down for my disciples the training that deals with the fundamentals of the spiritual life in order to rightly end suffering in every way.

an4.245:2.2.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, mayā sāvakānaṃ ādibrahmacariyikā sikkhā paññattā sabbaso sammā dukkhakkhayāya tathā tathā so tassā sikkhāya akhaṇḍakārī hoti acchiddakārī asabalakārī akammāsakārī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an4.245:2.2.eng: They undertake whatever training that deals with the fundamentals of the spiritual life I have laid down, keeping it intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred.

an4.245:2.3.eng: That’s how training is its benefit.

an4.245:3.1.eng: And how is wisdom its overseer?

an4.245:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, mayā sāvakānaṃ dhammā desitā sabbaso sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
an4.245:3.2.eng: I taught the Dhamma to my disciples in order to rightly end suffering in every way.

an4.245:3.3.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, mayā sāvakānaṃ dhammā desitā sabbaso sammā dukkhakkhayāya tathā tathāssa te dhammā paññāya samavekkhitā honti.
an4.245:3.3.eng: They examine with wisdom any teachings I taught them.

an4.245:3.4.eng: That’s how wisdom is its overseer.

an4.245:4.1.eng: And how is freedom its core?

an4.245:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, mayā sāvakānaṃ dhammā desitā sabbaso sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
an4.245:4.2.eng: I taught the Dhamma to my disciples in order to rightly end suffering in every way.

an4.245:4.3.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, mayā sāvakānaṃ dhammā desitā sabbaso sammā dukkhakkhayāya tathā tathāssa te dhammā vimuttiyā phusitā honti.
an4.245:4.3.eng: They experience through freedom any teachings I taught them.

an4.245:4.4.eng: That’s how freedom is its core.

an4.245:5.1.eng: And how is mindfulness its ruler?

an4.245:5.2.pli: ‘Iti aparipūraṃ vā ābhisamācārikaṃ sikkhaṃ paripūressāmi, paripūraṃ vā ābhisamācārikaṃ sikkhaṃ tattha tattha paññāya anuggahessāmī’ti—ajjhattaṃyeva sati sūpaṭṭhitā hoti.
an4.245:5.2.eng: Mindfulness is well established in oneself: ‘In this way I’ll fulfill the training dealing with supplementary regulations, or support with wisdom in every situation the training dealing with supplementary regulations I’ve already fulfilled.’

an4.245:5.3.pli: ‘Iti aparipūraṃ vā ādibrahmacariyikaṃ sikkhaṃ paripūressāmi, paripūraṃ vā ādibrahmacariyikaṃ sikkhaṃ tattha tattha paññāya anuggahessāmī’ti—ajjhattaṃyeva sati sūpaṭṭhitā hoti.
an4.245:5.3.eng: Mindfulness is well established in oneself: ‘In this way I’ll fulfill the training dealing with the fundamentals of the spiritual life, or support with wisdom in every situation the training dealing with the fundamentals of the spiritual life I’ve already fulfilled.’

an4.245:5.4.pli: ‘Iti asamavekkhitaṃ vā dhammaṃ paññāya samavekkhissāmi, samavekkhitaṃ vā dhammaṃ tattha tattha paññāya anuggahessāmī’ti—ajjhattaṃyeva sati sūpaṭṭhitā hoti.
an4.245:5.4.eng: Mindfulness is well established in oneself: ‘In this way I’ll examine with wisdom the teaching that I haven’t yet examined, or support with wisdom in every situation the teaching I’ve already examined.’

an4.245:5.5.pli: ‘Iti aphusitaṃ vā dhammaṃ vimuttiyā phusissāmi, phusitaṃ vā dhammaṃ tattha tattha paññāya anuggahessāmī’ti—ajjhattaṃyeva sati sūpaṭṭhitā hoti.
an4.245:5.5.eng: Mindfulness is well established in oneself: ‘In this way I’ll experience through freedom the teaching that I haven’t yet experienced, or support with wisdom in every situation the teaching I’ve already experienced.’

an4.245:5.6.eng: That’s how mindfulness is its ruler.

an4.245:5.7.pli: ‘Sikkhānisaṃsamidaṃ, bhikkhave, brahmacariyaṃ vussati paññuttaraṃ vimuttisāraṃ satādhipateyyan’ti,
an4.245:5.7.eng: ‘This spiritual life is lived with training as its benefit, with wisdom as its overseer, with freedom as its core, and with mindfulness as its ruler.’

an4.245:5.8.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttan”ti.
an4.245:5.8.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”

an4.246:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four ways of lying down.

an4.246:1.3.eng: The ways a corpse, a pleasure seeker, a lion, and a Realized One lie down.

an4.246:1.4.eng: And how does a corpse lie down?

an4.246:1.5.eng: Corpses usually lie flat on their backs.

an4.246:1.6.eng: This is called the way a corpse lies down.

an4.246:2.1.eng: And how does a pleasure seeker lie down?

an4.246:2.2.pli: Yebhuyyena, bhikkhave, kāmabhogī vāmena passena senti;
an4.246:2.2.eng: Pleasure seekers usually lie down on their left side.

an4.246:2.3.eng: This is called the way a pleasure seeker lies down.

an4.246:3.1.eng: And how does a lion lie down?

an4.246:3.2.pli: Sīho, bhikkhave, migarājā dakkhiṇena passena seyyaṃ kappeti, pāde pādaṃ accādhāya, antarasatthimhi naṅguṭṭhaṃ anupakkhipitvā.
an4.246:3.2.eng: The lion, king of beasts, lies down on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other, with his tail tucked between his thighs.

an4.246:3.3.pli: So paṭibujjhitvā purimaṃ kāyaṃ abbhunnāmetvā pacchimaṃ kāyaṃ anuviloketi.
an4.246:3.3.eng: When he wakes, he lifts his front quarters and checks his hind quarters.

an4.246:3.4.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sīho migarājā kiñci passati kāyassa vikkhittaṃ vā visaṭaṃ vā, tena, bhikkhave, sīho migarājā anattamano hoti.
an4.246:3.4.eng: If he sees that any part of his body is disordered or displaced, he is displeased.

an4.246:3.5.pli: Sace pana, bhikkhave, sīho migarājā na kiñci passati kāyassa vikkhittaṃ vā visaṭaṃ vā, tena, bhikkhave, sīho migarājā attamano hoti.
an4.246:3.5.eng: But if he sees that no part of his body is disordered or displaced, he is pleased.

an4.246:3.6.eng: This is called the way a lion lies down.

an4.246:4.1.eng: And how does a Realized One lie down?

an4.246:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, tathāgato vivicceva kāmehi …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.246:4.2.eng: It’s when a Realized One, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption … second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption.

an4.246:4.3.eng: This is called the way a Realized One lies down.

an4.246:4.4.eng: These are the four ways of lying down.”

an4.247:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four are worthy of a monument.

an4.247:1.3.pli: Tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho thūpāraho, paccekabuddho thūpāraho, tathāgatasāvako thūpāraho, rājā cakkavattī thūpāraho—
an4.247:1.3.eng: A Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha; an Independent Buddha; a disciple of a Realized One; and a wheel-turning monarch.

an4.247:1.4.eng: These four are worthy of a monument.”

an4.248:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four things lead to the growth of wisdom.

an4.248:1.3.eng: Associating with true persons, listening to the true teaching, rational application of mind, and practicing in line with the teaching.

an4.248:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro dhammā paññāvuddhiyā saṃvattantī”ti.
an4.248:1.4.eng: These four things lead to the growth of wisdom.”

an4.249:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four things are very helpful to a human being.

an4.249:1.3.eng: Associating with true persons, listening to the true teaching, rational application of mind, and practicing in line with the teaching.

an4.249:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro dhammā manussabhūtassa bahukārā hontī”ti.
an4.249:1.4.eng: These four things are very helpful to a human being.”

an4.25:1.1.pli: “Nayidaṃ, bhikkhave, brahmacariyaṃ vussati janakuhanatthaṃ, na janalapanatthaṃ, na lābhasakkārasilokānisaṃsatthaṃ, na itivādappamokkhānisaṃsatthaṃ, na ‘iti maṃ jano jānātū’ti.
an4.25:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, this spiritual life is not lived for the sake of fawning or flattering people, nor for the benefit of possessions, honor, or popularity, nor for the benefit of winning debates, nor thinking, ‘So let people know about me!’

an4.25:1.2.pli: Atha kho idaṃ, bhikkhave, brahmacariyaṃ vussati saṃvaratthaṃ pahānatthaṃ virāgatthaṃ nirodhatthanti.
an4.25:1.2.eng: This spiritual life is lived for the sake of restraint, giving up, fading away, and cessation.

an4.25:2.1.eng: The Buddha taught the spiritual life

an4.25:2.3.eng: but for the sake of restraint and giving up,

an4.25:2.4.eng: and because it culminates in extinguishment.

an4.25:2.5.eng: This is the path followed by the big-hearted,

an4.25:3.2.eng: as it was taught by the Buddha,

an4.250:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four ignoble expressions.

an4.250:1.3.pli: Adiṭṭhe diṭṭhavāditā, asute sutavāditā, amute mutavāditā, aviññāte viññātavāditā—
an4.250:1.3.eng: Saying you’ve seen, heard, thought, or known something, but you haven’t.

an4.250:1.4.eng: These are the four ignoble expressions.”

an4.251:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four noble expressions.

an4.251:1.3.pli: Adiṭṭhe adiṭṭhavāditā, asute asutavāditā, amute amutavāditā, aviññāte aviññātavāditā—
an4.251:1.3.eng: Saying you haven’t seen, heard, thought, or known something, and you haven’t.

an4.251:1.4.eng: These are the four noble expressions.”

an4.252:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four ignoble expressions.

an4.252:1.3.pli: Diṭṭhe adiṭṭhavāditā, sute asutavāditā, mute amutavāditā, viññāte aviññātavāditā—
an4.252:1.3.eng: Saying you haven’t seen, heard, thought, or known something, and you have.

an4.252:1.4.eng: These are the four ignoble expressions.”

an4.253:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four noble expressions.

an4.253:1.3.pli: Diṭṭhe diṭṭhavāditā, sute sutavāditā, mute mutavāditā, viññāte viññātavāditā—
an4.253:1.3.eng: Saying you’ve seen, heard, thought, or known something, and you have.

an4.253:1.4.eng: These are the four noble expressions.”

an4.254:1.3.eng: There are things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge.

an4.254:1.4.eng: There are things that should be given up by direct knowledge.

an4.254:1.5.eng: There are things that should be developed by direct knowledge.

an4.254:1.6.eng: There are things that should be realized by direct knowledge.

an4.254:2.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā pariññeyyā?
an4.254:2.1.eng: And what are the things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge?

an4.254:2.3.pli: ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā pariññeyyā.
an4.254:2.3.eng: These are called the things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge.

an4.254:3.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā pahātabbā?
an4.254:3.1.eng: And what are the things that should be given up by direct knowledge?

an4.254:3.2.eng: Ignorance and craving for continued existence.

an4.254:3.3.pli: ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā pahātabbā.
an4.254:3.3.eng: These are called the things that should be given up by direct knowledge.

an4.254:4.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā bhāvetabbā?
an4.254:4.1.eng: And what are the things that should be developed by direct knowledge?

an4.254:4.3.pli: ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā bhāvetabbā.
an4.254:4.3.eng: These are called the things that should be developed by direct knowledge.

an4.254:5.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā sacchikātabbā?
an4.254:5.1.eng: And what are the things that should be realized by direct knowledge?

an4.254:5.3.pli: ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā sacchikātabbā.
an4.254:5.3.eng: These are called the things that should be realized by direct knowledge.

an4.255:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four ignoble searches.

an4.255:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco attanā jarādhammo samāno jarādhammaṃyeva pariyesati;
an4.255:1.3.eng: Someone liable to old age searches only for what grows old.

an4.255:1.4.eng: Someone liable to sickness searches only for what gets sick.

an4.255:1.5.eng: Someone liable to death searches only for what dies.

an4.255:1.6.eng: Someone liable to become corrupted searches only for what is defiled.

an4.255:1.7.eng: These are the four ignoble searches.

an4.255:2.1.eng: There are these four noble searches.

an4.255:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco attanā jarādhammo samāno jarādhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā ajaraṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati;
an4.255:2.3.eng: Someone who is liable to grow old, knowing the drawback in what grows old, searches for that which is free of old age, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment.

an4.255:2.4.pli: attanā byādhidhammo samāno byādhidhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā abyādhiṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati;
an4.255:2.4.eng: Someone who is liable to get sick, knowing the drawback in what gets sick, searches for that which is free of sickness, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment.

an4.255:2.5.pli: attanā maraṇadhammo samāno maraṇadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā amataṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati;
an4.255:2.5.eng: Someone who is liable to die, knowing the drawback in what dies, searches for that which is free of death, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment.

an4.255:2.6.pli: attanā saṅkilesadhammo samāno saṅkilesadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā asaṅkiliṭṭhaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati.
an4.255:2.6.eng: Someone liable to become corrupted, knowing the drawback in what is defiled, searches for the undefiled supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment.

an4.255:2.7.eng: These are the four noble searches.”

an4.256:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four ways of being inclusive.

an4.256:1.3.eng: Giving, kindly words, taking care, and equality.

an4.256:1.4.eng: These are the four ways of being inclusive.”

an4.257:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mālukyaputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā mālukyaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.257:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Māluṅkyaputta went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an4.257:2.1.pli: “Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
an4.257:2.1.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

an4.257:2.2.pli: “Ettha idāni, mālukyaputta, kiṃ dahare bhikkhū vakkhāma;
an4.257:2.2.eng: “Well now, Māluṅkyaputta, what are we to say to the young monks,

an4.257:2.3.pli: yatra hi nāma tvaṃ jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako tathāgatassa saṅkhittena ovādaṃ yācasī”ti.
an4.257:2.3.eng: when even an old man like you, elderly and senior, asks the Realized One for brief advice?”

an4.257:2.4.pli: “Desetu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ; desetu sugato saṅkhittena dhammaṃ. Appeva nāmāhaṃ bhagavato bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājāneyyaṃ; appeva nāmāhaṃ bhagavato bhāsitassa dāyādo assan”ti.
an4.257:2.4.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief! May the Holy One teach me the Dhamma in brief! Hopefully I can understand the meaning of what the Buddha says! Hopefully I can be an heir of the Buddha’s teaching!”

an4.257:3.1.pli: “Cattārome, mālukyaputta, taṇhuppādā yattha bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati.
an4.257:3.1.eng: “Māluṅkyaputta, there are four things that give rise to craving in a mendicant.

an4.257:3.3.pli: Cīvarahetu vā, mālukyaputta, bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati.

an4.257:3.4.pli: Piṇḍapātahetu vā, mālukyaputta, bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati.

an4.257:3.5.pli: Senāsanahetu vā, mālukyaputta, bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati.

an4.257:3.6.pli: Itibhavābhavahetu vā, mālukyaputta, bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati.
an4.257:3.6.eng: or rebirth in this or that state.

an4.257:3.7.pli: Ime kho, mālukyaputta, cattāro taṇhuppādā yattha bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati.
an4.257:3.7.eng: These are the four things that give rise to craving in a mendicant.

an4.257:3.8.pli: Yato kho, mālukyaputta, bhikkhuno taṇhā pahīnā hoti ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā, ayaṃ vuccati, mālukyaputta, ‘bhikkhu acchecchi taṇhaṃ, vivattayi saṃyojanaṃ, sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassā’”ti.
an4.257:3.8.eng: That craving is given up by a mendicant, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future. Then they’re called a mendicant who has cut off craving, cast off the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.”

an4.257:4.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mālukyaputto bhagavatā iminā ovādena ovadito uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
an4.257:4.1.eng: When Māluṅkyaputta had been given this advice by the Buddha, he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

an4.257:4.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mālukyaputto eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
an4.257:4.2.eng: Then Māluṅkyaputta, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

an4.257:4.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
an4.257:4.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

an4.257:4.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā mālukyaputto arahataṃ ahosīti.
an4.257:4.4.eng: And Venerable Māluṅkyaputta became one of the perfected.

an4.258:1.1.pli: “Yāni kānici, bhikkhave, kulāni bhogesu mahattaṃ pattāni na ciraṭṭhitikāni bhavanti, sabbāni tāni catūhi ṭhānehi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena.
an4.258:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when families don’t stay wealthy for long, it’s always for one or more of these four reasons.

an4.258:1.3.pli: Naṭṭhaṃ na gavesanti, jiṇṇaṃ na paṭisaṅkharonti, aparimitapānabhojanā honti, dussīlaṃ itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā ādhipacce ṭhapenti.
an4.258:1.3.eng: They don’t look for what’s lost; they don’t repair old things; they eat and drink too much; or they put an unethical woman or man in charge.

an4.258:1.4.pli: Yāni kānici, bhikkhave, kulāni bhogesu mahattaṃ pattāni na ciraṭṭhitikāni bhavanti, sabbāni tāni imehi catūhi ṭhānehi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena.
an4.258:1.4.eng: When families don’t stay wealthy for long, it’s always for one or more of these four reasons.

an4.258:2.1.pli: Yāni kānici, bhikkhave, kulāni bhogesu mahattaṃ pattāni ciraṭṭhitikāni bhavanti, sabbāni tāni catūhi ṭhānehi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena.
an4.258:2.1.eng: When families do stay wealthy for long, it’s always for one or more of these four reasons.

an4.258:2.3.pli: Naṭṭhaṃ gavesanti, jiṇṇaṃ paṭisaṅkharonti, parimitapānabhojanā honti, sīlavantaṃ itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā ādhipacce ṭhapenti.
an4.258:2.3.eng: They look for what’s lost; they repair old things; they eat and drink in moderation; and they put an ethical woman or man in charge.

an4.258:2.4.pli: Yāni kānici, bhikkhave, kulāni bhogesu mahattaṃ pattāni ciraṭṭhitikāni bhavanti, sabbāni tāni imehi catūhi ṭhānehi, etesaṃ vā aññatarenā”ti.
an4.258:2.4.eng: When families do stay wealthy for long, it’s always for one or more of these four reasons.”

an4.259:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño bhadro assājānīyo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.259:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a fine royal thoroughbred with four factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and reckoned a factor of kingship.

an4.259:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño bhadro assājānīyo vaṇṇasampanno ca hoti balasampanno ca javasampanno ca ārohapariṇāhasampanno ca.
an4.259:1.3.eng: It’s when a fine royal thoroughbred is beautiful, strong, fast, and well-proportioned.

an4.259:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño bhadro assājānīyo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.259:1.4.eng: A fine royal thoroughbred with these four factors is worthy of a king. …

an4.259:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an4.259:2.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with four qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an4.259:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vaṇṇasampanno ca hoti balasampanno ca javasampanno ca ārohapariṇāhasampanno ca.
an4.259:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is beautiful, strong, fast, and well proportioned.

an4.259:3.1.eng: And how is a mendicant beautiful?

an4.259:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an4.259:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an4.259:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vaṇṇasampanno hoti.
an4.259:3.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is beautiful.

an4.259:4.1.eng: And how is a mendicant strong?

an4.259:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
an4.259:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

an4.259:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu balasampanno hoti.
an4.259:4.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is strong.

an4.259:5.1.eng: And how is a mendicant fast?

an4.259:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an4.259:5.2.eng: It’s when they truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an4.259:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu javasampanno hoti.
an4.259:5.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is fast.

an4.259:6.1.eng: And how is a mendicant well proportioned?

an4.259:6.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant receives robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an4.259:6.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ārohapariṇāhasampanno hoti.
an4.259:6.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is well proportioned.

an4.259:7.1.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an4.259:7.1.eng: A mendicant with these four qualities … is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an4.26:1.1.pli: “Ye te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū kuhā thaddhā lapā siṅgī unnaḷā asamāhitā, na me te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū māmakā.
an4.26:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, those mendicants who are deceivers and flatterers, pompous and fake, insolent, and scattered: those mendicants are no followers of mine.

an4.26:1.2.pli: Apagatā ca te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū imasmā dhammavinayā, na ca te imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ viruḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjanti.
an4.26:1.2.eng: They’ve left this teaching and training, and they don’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.

an4.26:1.3.pli: Ye ca kho te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū nikkuhā nillapā dhīrā atthaddhā susamāhitā, te kho me, bhikkhave, bhikkhū māmakā.
an4.26:1.3.eng: But those mendicants who are genuine, not flatterers, attentive, amenable, and serene: those mendicants are followers of mine.

an4.26:1.4.pli: Anapagatā ca te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū imasmā dhammavinayā. Te ca imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ viruḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjantīti.
an4.26:1.4.eng: They haven’t left this teaching and training, and they achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.

an4.26:2.1.eng: Those who are deceivers and flatterers, <j>pompous and fake,

an4.26:2.3.eng: these don’t grow in the teaching

an4.26:2.4.eng: that was taught by the perfected Buddha.

an4.26:3.1.eng: But those who are genuine, not flatterers, attentive,

an4.26:3.3.eng: these do grow in the teaching

an4.26:3.4.eng: that was taught by the perfected Buddha.”
